Expectation1: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation1: The supervisor has asked you to move a stack of unused materials to a different storage area sometime before the end of the day.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: They plan to spend the day lounging at home with immediate family.
Story:
I woke up early, planning to spend the day at home with my family. It was a rare day off, and I wore my comfortable, modest clothes—loose pants and a long-sleeved shirt, just as my faith guides me. My mother was already preparing breakfast, and I looked forward to a peaceful day. But then my phone buzzed. It was my supervisor from the construction site. He needed me to come in, just for a few hours, to move a stack of unused materials to a different storage area before the end of the day. 

I knew what the job would require: heavy lifting, sweating under the sun, and probably getting dirty. The usual work clothes—short sleeves, sometimes even shorts—made it easier to move and stay cool. But I couldn’t ignore my beliefs. I felt the pressure from both sides: my supervisor expected me to work efficiently, not slowed down by extra layers, while my faith expected me to dress modestly, even if it made the work harder. I stood in my room, staring at my closet, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing down on me.
